body:
Perhaps @javiercn can help us here, based on  https://github.com/xunit/xunit/issues/1499#issuecomment-339510146:

> In general there are a few things that are usually required for MVC to run E2E test correctly, but usually these things are only related to Views, which is what is tripping me off.

I personally don't know what's required to get these things to work correctly.

You need to do the following:
* Copy your the deps file of the project under test to the test project bin folder.
* Disable shadow copy (you can put an xunit.runner.json file on your bin folder for this).
* Set the content root to the application under test path

References:
Add the msbuild file below to automatically copy the deps file.
https://github.com/aspnet/Mvc/blob/dev/src/Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Testing/build/netstandard2.0/Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Testing.targets
Use a method like the one below to set the content root path relative to your solution file:
https://github.com/aspnet/Hosting/blob/dev/src/Microsoft.AspNetCore.TestHost/WebHostBuilderExtensions.cs#L52

@javiercn @bradwilson thank you for the guidance! I believe all what you mentioned is done in [my repro](https://github.com/sergeysolovev/xunit-mvc-repro) and it really works using `dotnet test`, but not `dotnet xunit`.

FYI, @javiercn, the `2.1.0-alpha1-27377` build of `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Testing` is broken in several ways (the fixture class cannot be a fixture in xUnit.net, it fails when using `dotnet xunit`, etc.).

@bradwilson yes, this kind of code is not reliable for production, but for a repro I think it's OK. It points out to the right folder.

>It would be better to use a known location (like typeof(WebSite).Assembly.Location) rather than Directory.GetCurrentDirectory().

`typeof(WebSite).Assembly.Location` will lead us to the output folder of the test project, while I actually need the website's content root folder.

P.S. I wish I could use WebHostBuilderExtensions, suggested by @javiercn, but it's not available as a nuget package yet, unfortunately.

@javiercn The issue appears to be your reliance upon `AppContext.BaseDirectory`, which points to `dotnet-xunit.dll`'s package folder when running `dotnet xunit`. This is not only the case in your fixture, but also in the `WebHostBuilderExtensions` file you pointed to earlier.
The fact that this folder is not pointing to the right place may be the source of the original issue, too, if MVC is relying on `AppContext.BaseDirectory` to point somewhere specific.

At this point, I'm fairly confident that this is an issue with MVC's reliance upon `AppContext.BaseDirectory` as the issue, and willing to concede that full MVC testing with `dotnet xunit` is probably not going to be possible until this is fixed.

@bradwilson üëç sounds right to me
@javiercn too bad you're using `dotnet test` instead of `dotnet xunit` for running your xunit tests, since the former doesn't fully utilize parallelization features of xunit and usually has longer turnaround time. It's supposed to be important for ASP.NET Core MVC testing, since you have lots of CI builds, running every day, each build taking ~13 minutes to accomplish.
